Class Option<T>

The Option class works like a Nullable<T>, but for reference types as well as primitive types. It is intended to replace the use of null as a value.

Inheritance
System.Object
Option<T>
Namespace: FunctionalLink.Next
Assembly: FunctionalLink.Next.dll
Syntax
public class Option<T> : Object
Type Parameters
Name Description
T

The type of the optional value
Remarks

As an example, the following code:

public static string ReadFile(string filename) =>
    File.Exists(filename)
        ? File.ReadAllText(filename)
        : null;

Can be rewritten as:

public static Option<string> ReadFile(string filename) =>
    File.Exists(filename)
        ? Some(File.ReadAllText(filename))
        : None();

The idea here is that the method signature is telling you explicitly that a return value might not be possible here, rather than returning an unexpected null.

Methods

And<TOther, TResult>(Option<TOther>, Func<T, TOther, TResult>)

Provides a way to combine two Options with values together into a new type. This is akin to 'Join' in Linq.

Declaration
public Option<TResult> And<TOther, TResult>(Option<TOther> other, Func<T, TOther, TResult> selector)
Parameters
Type Name Description
Option<TOther> other

Another Option to combine with the current Option
System.Func<T, TOther, TResult> selector

The function that combines the two values together and produces a new value
Returns
Type Description
Option<TResult>

An Option of the new result type
Type Parameters
Name Description
TOther

The type of the other Option
TResult

The type of the new TOption

And<TOther, TResult>(Func<Option<TOther>>, Func<T, TOther, TResult>)

Provides a way to combine two Options with values together into a new type. This is akin to 'Join' in Linq.

In this overload, the other Option is evaluated lazily.

HasValue(out T)

Used as a way to deconstruct an Option and retrieve the internal value, if it exists.

Declaration
public bool HasValue(out T value)
Parameters
Type Name Description
T value

The internal value of the Option
Returns
Type Description
System.Boolean

True if the Option contains a value. Otherwise false
Remarks

For example:

var user = FindUser(userId); // returns an Option
if (user.HasValue(out var value))
{
    ... // do something
}

Match(Action<T>, Action<None>)

Another way to deconstruct an Option and run an specific Action for each state it may be in. If the Option contains a value, onSome is executed. Otherwise, onNone is executed.

Declaration
public void Match(Action<T> onSome, Action<None> onNone)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.Action<T> onSome

The action to execute if the Option contains a value
System.Action<None> onNone

The action to execute if the Option does not contain a value
Remarks
var user = FindUser(userId); // returns an Option
user.Match(
    some => Console.WriteLine($"Hello {some}"),
    none => Console.WriteLine("User not found!"));

Match<TResult>(Func<T, TResult>, Func<None, TResult>)

Another way to deconstruct an Option and run an specific Func for each state it may be in. If the Option contains a value, onSome is executed. Otherwise, onNone is executed. Both functions must have the same return type.

Declaration
public TResult Match<TResult>(Func<T, TResult> onSome, Func<None, TResult> onNone)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.Func<T, TResult> onSome

The function to execute if the Option contains a value
System.Func<None, TResult> onNone

The function to execute if the Option does not contain a value
Returns
Type Description
TResult

The result of onSome or onNone depending on the state of the Option
Type Parameters
Name Description
TResult

The type of the result returned from both functions
Remarks
var user = FindUser(userId); // returns an Option
var username = user.Match(
    some => some.Username),
    none => "Mystery Person");

Console.WriteLine($"Hello {username}");

Maybe(T)

This is an alternate constructor for creating an Option from an unknown nullable value.

Declaration
public static Option<T> Maybe(T value)
Parameters
Type Name Description
T value

The target value
Returns
Type Description
Option<T>

An Option in the Some state if value is not null. Otherwise in the None state
Remarks

These are equivalent constructors:

value.Maybe();
Maybe(value);
Option.Maybe(value);
Option<int>.Maybe(value);

None()

The constructor for an Option with no value.

Declaration
public static Option<T> None()
Returns
Type Description
Option<T>

An Option in the None state
Remarks

These are equivalent constructors:

None();
Option.None();
Option<int>.None();

Or(Option<T>)

Provides a way of chaining two Options together returning whichever Option has a value. If a value exists in current Option, the current Option is carried forward. Otherwise, the alternate Option is carried forward.

Declaration
public Option<T> Or(Option<T> alt)
Parameters
Type Name Description
Option<T> alt

The alternate Option to use if the current Option has no value
Returns
Type Description
Option<T>

Either the current Option or the alternate Option based on their states

Or(Func<Option<T>>)

Provides a way of chaining two Options together returning whichever Option has a value. If a value exists in current Option, the current Option is carried forward. Otherwise, the alternate Option is carried forward.

In this version, the alternate Option is evaluated lazily via the given function.

Declaration
public Option<T> Or(Func<Option<T>> alt)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.Func<Option<T>> alt

The alternate Option to use if the current Option has no value
Returns
Type Description
Option<T>

Either the current Option or the alternate Option based on their states

Some(T)

The constructor for an Option that contains a value.

Declaration
public static Option<T> Some(T value)
Parameters
Type Name Description
T value

The value to contain
Returns
Type Description
Option<T>

An Option in the Some state with the given value
Remarks

These are equivalent constructors:

Some(123);
Option.Some(123);
Option<int>.Some(123);

Then(Action<T>)

If the Option contains a value, then the given action will be executed.

Declaration
public Option<T> Then(Action<T> f)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.Action<T> f

The Action to execute if the Option contains a value
Returns
Type Description
Option<T>

The Option returns itself in this case

Then<TResult>(Func<T, TResult>)

If the Option contains a value, then the given function will be executed and the result will be passed to the next function. This overload is akin to 'Map' or 'Select' in other programming contexts.

Declaration
public Option<TResult> Then<TResult>(Func<T, TResult> f)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.Func<T, TResult> f

The function to execute if the Option contains a value
Returns
Type Description
Option<TResult>

An Option of the new type of TResult
Type Parameters
Name Description
TResult

The type of the result returned from the given function

Then<TResult>(Func<T, Option<TResult>>)

If the Option contains a value, then the given function will be executed and the result will be passed to the next function. This overload is akin to 'Bind' or 'SelectMany' in other programming contexts.

Declaration
public Option<TResult> Then<TResult>(Func<T, Option<TResult>> f)
Parameters
Type Name Description
System.Func<T, Option<TResult>> f

The function to execute if the Option contains a value
Returns
Type Description
Option<TResult>

An Option of the new type of TResult
Type Parameters
Name Description
TResult

The type of the result returned from the given function

ValueOr(T)

A way of deconstructing an Option and retrieving the value contained with, if it exists. If a value exists, it is return. Otherwise, the alternate value is returned.

Declaration
public T ValueOr(T alt)
Parameters
Type Name Description
T alt

The alternate value to return if the Option does not contain a value
Returns
Type Description
T

Either the value within the Option or the alternate value

Operators

Implicit(None to Option<T>)

An implicit conversion operator used to make constructing Options require less syntax.

Declaration
public static implicit operator Option<T>(None none)
Parameters
Type Name Description
None none

The None value to convert
Returns
Type Description
Option<T>

An Option in a None state
Remarks

Typically, this operator is used like so:

public static Option<int> Divide(int a, int b) =>
    b != 0
        ? Some(a / b)
        : None(); // this None is implicitly converted to Option<int>

To avoid the implicit conversion, use the 'None' Option constructor directly:

public static Option<int> Divide(int a, int b) =>
    b != 0
        ? Option<int>.Some(a / b)
        : Option<int>.None(); // no implicit conversion is done here

ObjectExtensions.Enumerate<T>(T)
ObjectExtensions.Ignore(Object)
ObjectExtensions.Maybe<T>(T)
